channel.title: UPS Compatability
channel.description:
kk so i want a ups for my server so it will automatically shutdown when theres a power cut, and MAYBE even run a few scripts.
i think some ups's are just basic batteries which last for a certain amount of time and just cut the power when the battery runs out.
i've found this because it's cheap and apparently shuts down the computer when the power goes out
http://overclockers.co.uk/showproduct.php?prodid=UP-036-AP - thats actually out of stock, but this has a similar description.. http://overclockers.co.uk/showproduct.php?prodid=UP-034-AP
it doesn't say anything about linux tho, and im not installing windows on my server just so i can use a ups. is it likely to work with linux?

item.title: UPS Compatability
item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

[quote=“xx matty xx, post:14, topic:332801”]i ended up buying this one, http://www.overclockers.co.uk/showproduct.php?prodid=UP-000-CY&groupid=702&catid=55&subcat=1208

it’s awesome, it lets you run your own bash scripts at different percentages of battery power so u can do cool stuff like login to irc and pm yourself.[/quote]

Nice

item.title: UPS Compatability
item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

runescape3dude:

I have never had a problem with any of these filesystems. But I didn’t use FAT, I used FAT32 (Is there any difference?)

No idea, but you shouldn’t have any problems as long as its used as your main file system. Meaning that its the one your opearting system is on and it comes on when your computer comes on and goes off when you shut down your computer properly.

Read full topic

item.title: UPS Compatability
item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

Mopman:

fair enough, i have a lot more experience with ext3 than i do ntfs i assumed it would be roughly as stable

FAT32 < NTFS < EXT3 or HFS Journaled

: )

Read full topic

item.title: UPS Compatability
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

fair enough, i have a lot more experience with ext3 than i do ntfs i assumed it would be roughly as stable

Read full topic

item.title: UPS Compatability
item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

You don’t want to do it on NTFS, ive had some bag experiences with NTFS where the drive wasn’t even being written to and I unplugged the USB cable and lost about 20GB of movies. Now ive got smart and im using a HFS Journaled File System, no problem’s since and I can unplug the drive whenever I fell like without worry of losing 20gb of files.

Read full topic

item.title: UPS Compatability
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

on FAT, killing the power during writes definitely is a very bad idea

on ntfs and other journalled fs’s, its not that bad. i mean, you should still properly shutdown, but its wayy more resilient than it was

edit: and yes ubuntu uses ext3 by default which is journalled

edit2: oh and as for actually physically breaking drives, nah thatll never happen. way way wayyy back in the day, when we had an amstrad 1580 or w/e they were, the predecessor to the 1640, it had a command “park” which locked the disk heads into place, which had to be run before you shutdown. i assume that was to stop physical damage and thats where the rumour comes from, but on modern drives its not an issue

Read full topic

item.title: UPS Compatability
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

o ok i think i’ll save my money then… i’ve just had people telling me from the age of like 7 that hard shutdowns will instantly annihilate ur pc

Read full topic

item.title: UPS Compatability
item.dc:creator: @lawl lawl
item.description:
@lawl wrote:

i shut down randomly all the time and ive never had anything unfixable happen

Read full topic

item.title: UPS Compatability
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

does ubuntu use a journaling file system?

and it wont damage the hardware? i could barely afford to pay for my server as it is and have had to upgrade small parts month by month. there’s no way i’d be able to replace the psu or another hd.

Read full topic

item.title: UPS Compatability
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

uh, well obviously itll corrupt the data that was being written, but as long as you’re using a journalled filesystem i doubt itd fuck much else

its probably theoretically possible but i treat my pcs like shit w/rgds to powering down midoperations and ive never lost data on ext3

it wont damage the hd since about 1980

Read full topic

item.title: UPS Compatability
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:2, topic:332801”]thats pretty much the definitely of a ups… most of the cheaper units dont have any method of monitoring, because theyre not designed specifically for pcs.

tbh if the only reason you want one is for clean shutdowns, i wouldnt bother. what app really cares if its cleanly shutdown?[/quote]If a program is writing to the HD and the power cuts out, this can corrupt the data and even damage the HD can’t it?

In the past I’ve had MySQL tables crash because of power failures, but I’ve been lucky because I managed to repair them using the standard query.

Read full topic

The CS UPS from APC safeguards your business computers against valuable data loss during power outtages and/or spikes.
